thread.title: Stanford's Christian McCaffrey runs wild in a 56-35 victory over UCLA
thread.title_full: Stanford's Christian McCaffrey runs wild in a 56-35 victory over UCLA

author:
Jon Wilner

jwilner@mercurynews.com
title: Stanford's Christian McCaffrey runs wild in a 56-35 victory over UCLA
text:
Posted: 10/15/2015 10:18:08 PM PDT Updated: 10/16/2015 12:27:05 AM PDT STANFORD -- With tailback Christian McCaffrey racing to an epic night, Stanford charged into the playoff discussion with a 56-35 victory over 18th-ranked UCLA on Thursday. 
McCaffrey scored four touchdowns and gained 369 all-purpose yards (rushing, receiving, return), the most by a Football Bowl Subdivision player this season. 
"I had a couple like that in high school,'' said McCaffrey, who wears uniform No. 5 because of his idol, former USC running back Reggie Bush. "Those are the games people dream of. But there's still no trophy.'' 
His rushing total of 243 yards broke Toby Gerhart's six-year-old school record. He returned a kickoff 96 yards, uncorked a 70-yard touchdown run and averaged 13.1 yards every time he touched the ball. Stanford Cardinal's Francis Owusu (6) makes a 41 touchdown catch against UCLA Bruins' Jaleel Wadood (2) in the third quarter at Stanford Stadium in Stanford, Calif, on Thursday, Oct. 15, 2015. (Nhat V. Meyer/Bay Area News Group) (Nhat V. Meyer) 
"It says a lot about the front seven,'' McCaffrey said of the offensive line. "The guys working hard allows me to make plays." 
And yet, McCaffrey did not produce the play of the game. 
That came courtesy of receiver Francis Owusu on a flea flicker pass from quarterback Kevin Hogan. Owusu reached around UCLA safety Jaleel Wadood and somehow pinned the ball on Wadood's back, then held on as they tumbled to the grass. 
"I was squeezing (the ball) for my life,'' Owusu said. 
Said McCaffrey: "I'm still at a loss for words, It was one of the most amazing things I've seen in my life." 
Add another impressive performance by Hogan, efficiency on third down and a bevy of UCLA miscues, and 15th-ranked Stanford rolled to its eighth consecutive victory over the Bruins and topped the 40-point mark for the fourth game in a row. Advertisement 
With a home-heavy schedule down the stretch, the sizzling Cardinal (5-1, 4-0) is seemingly well positioned to not only win the division but contend for a spot in the semifinals on New Year's Eve. 
"We're playing lights out,'' Owusu said. 'We're happy to keep this going.'' 
Stanford opened the scoring early in the first quarter, when cornerback Alijah Holder stepped in front of an underthrown sideline pass by UCLA's Josh Rosen. Holder grabbed the ball, eluded a tackler and produced a nifty 31-yard interception return for a touchdown. Stanford Cardinal's Alijah Holder (13) celebrates his 31 yard interception and touchdown against the UCLA Bruins in the first quarter at Stanford Stadium in Stanford, Calif, on Thursday, Oct. 15, 2015. (Nhat V. Meyer/Bay Area News Group) ( Nhat V. Meyer ) 
It was Stanford's first Pick 6 since the Jan. '14 Rose Bowl (Kevin Anderson) and only the fourth turnover the Cardinal has forced this season. 
The Bruins zoomed down the field as tailback Paul Perkins unleashed a dazzling 43-yard run that took UCLA into the red zone. But two penalties killed the drive and the Bruins settled for a field goal. 
The big plays continued — immediately. McCaffrey returned the ensuing kickoff 96 yards to set up a short touchdown pass from Hogan to tight end Austin Hooper, giving the Cardinal a 14-3 lead. 
The Bruins wasted no time answering. On first down, Rosen and receiver Darren Andrews connected on 70-yard catch-and-run touchdown. 
From there, the pace of scoring slowed — much to Stanford's liking. The Cardinal took 14 plays and more than seven minutes to push its advantage to 21-10 on Hogan's laser to Devon Cajuste. But the key plays took place well before the scoring strike, when Stanford converted third downs of 12 and 13 yards. Both times, Hogan hit Hooper, his favorite receiver. 
Less than one minute into the second quarter, the teams had combined for 31 points. There was more to come. McCaffrey charged nine yards for a touchdown midway through the quarter to cap a three-play drive, then scored on a 28-yard dash with 2:13 left before halftime. 
Early in the third quarter, the Cardinal squashed any chance of a UCLA comeback. It came in the form of a flea flicker. McCaffrey took the snap from center in the Wildcat formation, handed to tailback Bryce Love, who then flipped to Hogan. 
Hogan gathered himself, then tossed a 41-yard pass to Owusu in the end zone. Owusu reached around the back of a UCLA defender, grabbed the ball and held on. 
The play gave Stanford a 42-17 lead. 
"I can't describe that catch -- I can't understand what happened,'' coach David Shaw said. "I thought it was incomplete." 
Former Stanford all-conference safety John Lynch was the honorary captain. For more on college sports, see Jon Wilner's College Hotline at blogs.mercurynews.com/collegesports . Contact him at jwilner@mercurynews.com or 408-920-5716.
